scrum_roles.title: Scrum Roles
scrum_roles.content:
There are three main roles in a Scrum team:
 {roles} The Product Owner defines requirements and prioritises tasks. The Scrum Master ensures compliance with the Scrum process and removes obstacles. The development team implements the requirements and delivers functional products in sprints.

sprint_names.title: Sprint names
sprint_names.content: Sprint names help to clearly identify sprints and categorize them in a meaningful way. For example, they can be named numerically (e.g. "Sprint 1", "Sprint 2"), according to content focus (e.g. "Sprint house construction") or with a further alphabetical initial letter (e.g. "Amsterdam", "Berlin").

sprint_goal.title: Sprint Goal
sprint_goal.content: The sprint goal is the main objective that the team wants to achieve in the current sprint. It provides clear orientation and helps to keep the focus on the most important things during the entire sprint. A good sprint goal is precise, realistic and clear to the entire team, e.g. "Sketch the layout of the city."

user_stories.title: User stories
user_stories.content: User stories should be formulated clearly and precisely and reflect the user's perspective. They follow the format: "As a [role], I want [goal] to [benefit]." (e.g. "As a resident, I would like to have a road to get from my house to work.") Acceptance criteria should also be present. These are conditions that show when a task has been completed. (e.g. "The road has two lanes.")

story_points.title: Story points
story_points.content: Story points indicate the complexity of the user story. The Fibonacci sequence (1, 2, 3, 5, 8, 13 ...) is often used to record relative differences between the stories. Alternative estimation methods for user stories are T-shirt sizes (S, M, L, XL) or time-based estimation.

infobox.title: Sprint Review
infobox.content: The sprint review is used to present and review the finished increment of the product. The product owner (PO) therefore checks whether all user story (US) requirements have been met. If this has been done, the US is defined as accepted. The aim of the meeting is to inspect the product and discuss possible adjustments for the next sprints together with the stakeholders.

scrumplicity_guide.title: Welcome to the ScrumpliCity Guide!
scrumplicity_guide.overview: The ScrumpliCity guide provides you with all the important information about the game, detailed step-by-step instructions for your role as a tutor and joining instructions for learners. Further information on the Scrum process, which is not listed here for reasons of clarity, can be found at {link}.

introduction.title: Introduction
introduction.description: ScrumpliCity is an ideal first project to better understand and practically apply the Scrum process. Learners build a paper city from prefabricated crafting-templates, while the website guides them step by step through the various phases. Work is carried out in teams that are organised together in a room. A room therefore brings together several project teams - for example, a school class divided into four teams.

prerequisites.title: Prerequisites
prerequisites.description: Each team needs a laptop for the game. The learners use this to join the room and manage their user stories. As ScrumpliCity does not include a product backlog, teams will need to manage this externally - for example in an online tool or in the traditional way using sticky notes. The teams don't need glue to build the paper city, but they do need scissors and optional coloured pencils to customise the result. You can find more information about the crafting-templates in the instructions in the downloadable .zip folder.

scrum_content.title: Scrum content
scrum_content.description: At the beginning, the teams define their Definition of Done - this remains visible throughout the entire sprint in the detail box at the bottom right. In the sprint planning, they first determine a name for the sprint, then define a sprint goal and finally their user stories. These are estimated with story points by the learners, assigned to a team member and expanded with acceptance criteria in the description. During the construction phase, learners can view their user stories by clicking on them in the detail box and marking them as ‘completed’. In the sprint review, the product owner checks the completed tasks - the velocity is updated automatically. The sprint completion is the transition phase between two sprints. This is where the learners decide whether user stories that have not been accepted are discarded or carried over to the next sprint. Accepted stories are automatically archived. Finally, the learners should update the physical burn-down chart, which you can download together with the crafting-templates!

step_by_step.title: Step-by-step guide for tutors
step_by_step.description1: From the homepage, you can access the selection page via the ‘Get started!’ buttons. The ‘Tutor’ role takes you to the login page, which is currently only possible with an existing Microsoft account. If you select the ‘Learner’ role, you will be redirected to the room code entry page so that you can then play as a team.
step_by_step.caption1: Step 1: Role selection as a tutor
step_by_step.description2: Once you have successfully logged in, the website will automatically redirect you to the room overview. In the header, you have the option of changing the language from English to German, downloading the crafting templates or expanding the profile settings.  To play ScrumpliCity, you must create a new room at the bottom right.
step_by_step.caption2: Step 2: Room overview of the tutor
step_by_step.description3: You can make numerous settings when creating a room. You can change these again later on. The name of the room is only displayed in the room overview to make the room identifiable. You can also set the duration of the various phases, either with suggestions or your own input (up to 99 minutes). The total duration of the game is also displayed at the bottom right to make it easier to plan.
step_by_step.caption3: Step 3: Create room with name, number of sprints and phase duration
step_by_step.description4: Now that a room has been prepared for playing, we recommend downloading the crafting-templates by clicking on the centre button in the top right-hand corner. In the .zip folder you will find template sheets, a template for a burn-down chart and instructions with useful information, such as the required number of printed sheets per team.
step_by_step.description5: Click on the room to go to it's management page. This is where you are as a tutor while the game is running. You can adjust the room settings at the top right. Before the game can be started, you must generate a room code at the bottom right. The code will open in a new window so that you can easily project it onto another screen. Using this code, learners can join the room on scrumplicity.app/play.
step_by_step.caption5: Step 4: Download crafting-templates via the icon
step_by_step.description6: As soon as a room code has been generated, you can also copy it to the clipboard under the room name. An empty timer and the display for the current phase and sprint number will also appear. Once at least one team has joined, you can start the game by clicking the ‘Play’ button at the bottom right. As a tutor, you can delete teams or add or remove members at any time.
step_by_step.caption6: Step 6: Manage your teams and start the game!
